abstractContent.text: This paper 1 decdbes a computational treatment of the semantics of relational nouns.
It covers relational nouns such as "sister.and "commander; and focuses especially on a particular subcategory of them, called function nouns ('speed; "distance', "rating').
Rela-tional nouns are usually viewed as either requiring non-compositional semantic interpretation, or causing an undesirable proliferation of syntactic rules.
In contrast to this, we present a treatment which is both syntactically uniform and semantically compositional.

The core ideas of this treatment are: (1) The recognition of different levels of semantic analysis; in particular , the distinction between an English-oriented and a domain-oriented level of meaning representation.
(2) The analysis of relational nouns as denoting relation-extensions.
The paper shows how this approach handles a variety of linguistic constructions involving relational nouns.
The treatment presented here has been implemented in BBN's Spoken Language System, an experimental spoken language interface to a database/graphics system.
